content.user_title: Create isolated git worktrees for parallel development
content.value_statement: Managing multiple branches in a single git repository clutters your workspace. This skill creates isolated worktrees with smart directory selection and automatic safety verification to keep your main workspace clean while you work on features.
actual_capabilities: Creates isolated git worktrees for feature development
Smart directory selection with priority order
Auto-detects and runs project setup commands
Verifies clean test baseline before work begins
Supports Node.js, Rust, Python, and Go projects
limitations: Cannot create worktrees on bare repositories
Global worktrees outside project require manual cleanup
Does not manage worktree deletion or branch merging

use_cases.title: Isolated feature development
use_cases.description: Work on new features without cluttering your main workspace or interrupting current development flow

use_cases.title: Clean PR branches
use_cases.description: Create pristine branches for pull requests without affecting your active development environment

use_cases.title: Parallel worktree workflows
use_cases.description: Switch between tasks instantly by maintaining separate worktrees for different features or fixes

prompt_templates.title: Basic worktree creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the using-git-worktrees skill to create an isolated worktree for a new feature branch called feature-name

prompt_templates.title: Worktree with setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the using-git-worktrees skill to set up a worktree. Check for existing directories, verify gitignore, create at .worktrees-feature-name, run npm install and tests

prompt_templates.title: Global worktree location
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the using-git-worktrees skill to create a worktree at ~/.config/superpowers/worktrees-projectname-branchname. Skip gitignore check since this is outside the project

prompt_templates.title: Verification workflow
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating worktree with full safety checks
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the using-git-worktrees skill to create a worktree. Follow all safety steps: check CLAUDE.md for preferences, verify or add gitignore entry, run cargo test for Rust project, report the final path and test results

output_examples.input: Use the using-git-worktrees skill to create a worktree for an authentication feature
Create a worktree for a bugfix branch called hotfix-login
Set up a worktree for my Go project at the global location

best_practices: Always verify .gitignore contains worktree directory before creating project-local worktrees
Follow directory priority: existing directories > CLAUDE.md preferences > ask user
Run baseline tests to ensure worktree starts clean before implementing new features
anti_patterns: Skipping .gitignore verification allows worktree contents to accidentally enter version control
Assuming directory location without checking creates inconsistency across projects
Proceeding with failing tests makes it impossible to distinguish new bugs from pre-existing issues

faq.question: Which git versions support worktrees?
faq.answer: Git worktrees require git version 2.5 or higher. Most modern git installations support this feature.

faq.question: What determines worktree directory location?
faq.answer: Priority order: existing .worktrees/ or worktrees/ directories, then CLAUDE.md preferences, then user input.

faq.question: Can worktrees share the same .git directory?
faq.answer: Yes. Worktrees share the parent repository's .git directory while maintaining separate working trees.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using worktrees?
faq.answer: The skill verifies .gitignore before creating project-local worktrees to prevent accidental commits.

faq.question: Why did my worktree creation fail?
faq.answer: Common causes: git version below 2.5, bare repository, branch already has a worktree, or insufficient permissions.

faq.question: How does this compare to switching branches?
faq.answer: Worktrees keep multiple branches checked out simultaneously without switching, preserving uncommitted changes.
